ideally, you fix this to be compatible with jedi 0.17.x :smiley:

items.title: pyls doesn't initialize
items.body:
This is not a bug (I fixed my problem). I'm just putting it here for anyone else looking at the same error.

I updated the python virtual environment after installing the python-language-server. This caused *nvim* to print an error about
pyls failing to initialize and something about ujson<=1.35 not being met.

Checking, I had ujson==3.0.0 so, in bash, I entered:
`pip install 'ujson==1.35' --force-reinstall`

No more error message when opening a python file in nvim.

items.title: Workspace folders and linter settings
items.body:
If I have two workspace folders `a` and `b`, and there's `a/tox.ini` and `b/tox.ini`, then pycodestyle seems to only use the linter settings from whatever file was opened first in one of the workspace folders.

So I have line length set to 80 in `a/tox.ini`, and line length set to 120 in `b/tox.ini`, and if I open a file in `a`, then all files opened in `b` will get linter warnings about line lengths not respecting 80 columns max.

items.title: Pycodestyle fails to load if autopep8 is not installed
items.body:
I use Arch Linux, and I have installed pyls and pycodestyle through pacman (Arch's package manager). I have not installed autopep8. However, pyls fails to load the pycodestyle plugin if autopep8 isn't installed. If I install it, it starts working.

Here's a test file: 
```python
"""Test."""
asdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdfasdf = 1
```

Here are the pyls logs: [pyls.log](https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/files/4660808/pyls.log)

This also happens if I install pyls in a clean virtualenv.

items.title: [Question] - Is Python 2 support necessary?
items.body:
I've been diving more into the source code, and there is a bunch of compatibility check against Python 2. I wonder if this is still necessary since Python 2 is out of life since January this year.
Does LSP have any plans on moving out from Python 2 does it indent to keep support?
I understand that having support for Python 2 is nice, but it does tend to keep lots of hacky code around to support it :(.  

I fear the support of an obsolete/out of date language into a up-to-date tool such as LSP. I have a feeling that the more tools keep a compatibility with out of date tools, the more people will tend to continue using out-of-date technologies, but that's my 1cent. 

If there is any future plans on removing Python 2 support, I would be happy to contribute with that.

items.title: Support Jedi 0.17
items.body: Jedi 0.17 has been out since the 14th of April, it would be nice if it would be supported so the update can be shipped to distro repositories.

items.title: Does pyls need to sit in the virtualenv of the project?
items.body:
I am trying out `pyls` (with Emacs' `lsp-mode`). 

In a project with a with virtualenv which contains pandas , `pyls` does not give me any completions on pandas.

I have installed `pyls` in its own virtual env and  I am suspecting that `pyls` expects to be in the same virtualenv as the project. 

Is that correct? And if so, is there a way around it?

items.title: Signature and hover feature do not work when using virutal environment
items.body:
Hi!
I use `venv` to manage my packages. I don't want to install pyls in each virtual environment. I found feature in #680 works for me. I add my virtual environment via `jedi.environment` in my config file. The completion feature work well. However, I cannot get any signature help or hover information. These features work well for packages not installed in virtual environment.

My configuration looks like:

```
"pyls": {
    "plugins": {
        "jedi.environment": "/absolute/path/to/my/venv/directory"
    }
}
```

* OS: Arch Linux
* editor: neovim v0.4.3
* lsp client: coc.nvim v0.0.78
* pyls v0.31.10

items.title: Conflict between required pyflakes version
items.body:
Publication of pyflakes 2.2.0 version revealed a conflict in dependencies between python-language-server (pyflakes>=1.6.0) and flake8(pyflakes<2.2.0,>-2.1.0). 

I think the best solution would be to remove dependencies in python-language-server and rely only on flake8 definition.

items.title: Transform source in a plugin
items.body:
Hi,

Is there a hook I can use so that I can transform the source of the file before pyls works on it?

I want to make a plugin so that pyls can understand my custom codec from https://noseofyeti.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/examples.html

So far I've figured out I can do the following so pyls stops complaining about the coding being unrecognised.

```
from noseOfYeti.tokeniser.spec_codec import register

from pyls import hookimpl


@hookimpl(hookwrapper=True)
def pyls_initialize(config, workspace):
    register()
    yield
```

But as far as I can tell there isn't a way to then use the codec to transform the contents of the file.

items.title: flake8 and pyflakes plugins are not working on Atom at least on Linux (and maybe other OSes)
items.body:
This issue is being reported by multiple people, initially we thought it was `ide-python` https://github.com/lgeiger/ide-python/issues/191 but I think this is probably a pyls issue on Atom on at least Linux and maybe other OSes.

In a test conda environment, where I install only `conda install python-language-server`, if I configure `ide-python` in Atom to only enable flake8 and disable everything else and I open a python file I get no linting and the following console errors [atom-console-pyls-flake8.log](https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/files/4397758/atom-console-pyls-flake8.log)

It seems to have started happening with pyls >0.31.2

items.title: flake8 plugin using fragile stderr.read() call
items.body:
I'm using a combination of emacs, poetry, and pyls/flake8, and seeing instances where expected flake8 diagnostics are missing from the pyls response.  I've traced this back to a hanging stderr.read() call in the run_flake8() function:

https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/blob/f6df42cae186e5389e0332e9b8406bb24bd84d3e/pyls/plugins/flake8_lint.py#L61

According to the [Python docs](https://docs.python.org/2/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.Popen.stdin),  (scroll up a couple lines,) `Popen.communicate()` should be used rather than `Popen.stderr.read()` to avoid deadlocks due to "other OS pipe buffers filling up and blocking the child process" which appears to be what's happening in my situation.

items.title: Adapt to the last Jedi
items.body:
Hi,
Error happend with fresh installed python-language-server.
After check the error message, it cause by incompatable dependency that python-language-server depend on 0.14<=JEDI<0.16, while the pip actually install the last JEDI (0.16.0) when install pyls.

The workaround is change the setup.py to depend on JEDI 0.15.2.

Is there any plan to cachup with last JEDI (0.16.*)?

Thanks

The JEDI releases are:
https://github.com/davidhalter/jedi/releases

items.title: Flake8 plugin does not check content of unsaved buffer
items.body:
It seems like the way the plugin is written it uses the document.path in the flake8 argument to check for errors:

https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/blob/f6df42cae186e5389e0332e9b8406bb24bd84d3e/pyls/plugins/flake8_lint.py#L42-L45

Where pycodestyle would actually use the document.lines instead:

https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/blob/f6df42cae186e5389e0332e9b8406bb24bd84d3e/pyls/plugins/pycodestyle_lint.py#L33-L35

This seems wrong as the flake8 check would ignore the update to the current buffer and always check what is written to disk.  From the editor, you basically see all the signs/error lines to be incorrect.

For example, I'm using vim and use vim-lsp-settings, I have a configuration like:

```
    let g:lsp_settings['pyls'] = {
    \    'workspace_config': {'pyls': {'plugins': {
    \      'flake8': {'enabled': v:true,},
    \      'pycodestyle': {'enabled': v:false,},
    \      'pyflakes': {'enabled': v:false},
    \      'mccabe': {'enabled': v:false},
    \    }}}
    \  }
```

Say if you have a test.py file with this:
```
print(y)
```
Save the file and edit again, you'd see the line is flagged as error.

However, if you insert the line above it and add another print:

```
print(x)
print(y)
```
The result is that the error would still only appear on line 1 and NOT both lines since flake8 is run on the file saved on disk.  It does not pipe the buffer to it instead.

Flake8 can read from stdin so it should be possible to pipe the lines to the checker.  For instance:

```
cat test.py | flake8 -
```

items.title: LSP :: TypeError: py__call__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'arguments'
items.body:
# Description
When I try to complete this code:
```python
import subprocess
subprocess.run([]). <-- error happens here at the dot
```

I get the below exception:
```
LSP :: TypeError: py__call__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'arguments'
```

# Versions

Python version: 3.8.1

Python language server versions:
```
python-language-server==0.31.4
pyls-black==0.4.4
```

LSP client: emacs lsp-mode

items.title: Tests currently broken on develop
items.body: It seems that the test `test_snippets_completion` is currently broken on the branch `develop`. This also seems to be related to the recent `jedi` package upgrade to 0.15.2 from 0.15.1 on previous successful runs of CI.

items.title: Workspace folders not implemented completely
items.body:
The signature for didChangeWorkspaceFolders

```python
def m_workspace__did_change_workspace_folders(self, added=None, removed=None, **_kwargs):
```

assumes `added` and `removed` are children of the `params` field, but according to the spec they should be nested under `event`? (See https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-3-14/#workspace_didChangeWorkspaceFolders)


Results in: 
```
:: --> pyls workspace/didChangeWorkspaceFolders: {'event': {'removed': [], 'added': []}}
pyls: 2019-12-19 18:50:04,738 UTC - ERROR - pyls_jsonrpc.endpoint - Failed to handle notification workspace/didChangeWorkspaceFolders: {'event': {'removed': [], 'added': []}}
pyls: Traceback (most recent call last):
pyls: File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pyls_jsonrpc/endpoint.py", line 142, in _handle_notification
pyls: handler_result = handler(params)
pyls: File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pyls_jsonrpc/dispatchers.py", line 23, in handler
pyls: return method(**(params or {}))
pyls: File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pyls/python_ls.py", line 363, in m_workspace__did_change_workspace_folders
pyls: for removed_info in removed:
pyls: TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable
```

The server also does not take the initial list of workspaces from `initialize` - it only creates a single workspace for `rootUri`. Sending a `didChangeWorkspaceFolders` with an entry in `removed` that is not the _rootUri_ will result in a KeyError.

items.title: Deeptools error - Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve
items.body:
Hi,

I am currently doing an ATAC-seq analysis for a bioinformatics course, but I am a python beginner and I am having trouble navigating it. I have 6 sorted bam files and my instructions say to use deeptools to assess the correlation between them (multiBamSummary -> plotCorrelation) and also check how much of the genome is covered and at what depth (plotCoverage).

I have been trying to install deeptools on Anaconda2 prompt (both on Python 3.7 and 2.7 versions) following this tutorial: https://deeptools.readthedocs.io/en/develop/content/installation.html First I had an environment error that I solved with the code below, but now I get other errors and I can not find a solution online? I tried uninstalling and reinstalling anaconda and other packages, but it does not work.

The code that I used: conda create --name dianaenv python=2.7 conda activate dianaenv conda config --add channels bioconda conda install -c bioconda deeptools

The error: Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve. Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source. Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve. Solving environment: / Found conflicts! items.title: Allow the language server implementation to be used by other projects
items.body:
I have [this language server](https://github.com/suoto/hdl_checker/) that relies on `pyls.python_ls.PythonLanguageServer` for the [low level LSP interface](https://github.com/suoto/hdl_checker/blob/master/hdl_checker/lsp.py#L145), and I wonder if the language server logic - an abstract language server implementation if you will - could be extracted and made available as an independent Python module, so that I (and hopefully others) can use basically subclass `pyls.python_ls.PythonLanguageServer` directly, without other side effects like installing the pyls executable.

Not sure how often this is asked, I could fork this repo and remove the plugin portion, but would be great to hear your thoughts.

Thanks!

items.title: flake8 integration fails to ignore things that should be ignored
items.body:
eg if I have 

```
[flake8]
ignore = W503,E203
```

in `~/.config/flake8`, those errors are reported by `pyls` anyway.

I think what's going on is that `flake8` only filters results when passing them to its formatter, round about [here](https://github.com/PyCQA/flake8/blob/e0612597094234cd7acaad3d64b6c7071cdf1831/src/flake8/style_guide.py#L573). But `pyls`'s `flake8` plugin looks at the unfiltered results.

items.title: Goto definition goes to the stub and not the actual implementation
items.body:
I many cases, when i execute goto definition on a symbol it goes to the stub file instead of the actual implementation
```python
import os.path

os.path.dirname(...)
```
Invoke goto definition on `dirname`
it opens up the symbol location in "...\python\python37\lib\site-packages\jedi\third_party\typeshed\stdlib\2and3\ntpath.pyi"
while it should open "...\Python\Python37\Lib\ntpath.py"

items.body: Signed the contributor license agreement. Still blocked in #657. Could anyone take a look at the PR?

items.title: Completions are not provided for stub file unless it's located in the same folder as the .py file
items.body:
I have two files in one folder
mod.py
```python
def f(x):
    pass
```
and mod.pyi
```python
def f(x: int) -> int: ...
```
completions work fine
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33235928/66136186-55c47080-e5fb-11e9-8baa-2dc8d4b5fc76.png)

then
1. create a stubs folder and move mod.pyi to it
2. add a mypy.ini
```ini
[mypy]
mypy_path = stubs
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33235928/66135941-fa927e00-e5fa-11e9-8c54-faf79f67381d.png)
no completions are provided

items.title: function overloads returns are treated as unions
items.body:
I have two files:
mod.py
```python
def f(value):
    pass
```
and mod.pyi:
```python
from typing import List, Dict, overload


@overload
def f(value: List[str]) -> str: ...


@overload
def f(value: Dict[str, str]) -> Dict[str, str]: ...
```
I'm using pyls in sublime text with it's [LSP client](https://github.com/tomv564/LSP), I was testing completions in this case and it turned out that pyls does not consider the signature when providing completions but rather treats the result of any call to the function `f` as a Union of the return types of its overloads (`Union[str, Dict[str, str]]`)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33235928/66006834-62887d80-e4b0-11e9-9851-334e1c58605e.png)

I think it should instead consider the return type per function signature and provide completions accordingly, and if there's no overload variant for a certain call then it should not provide completions at all.

items.title: Overloads signature
tests failing because of latest pylint release
items.body:
Looks like the latest release of pylint is more precise with the column where the syntax error is.

### The test

We are testing pylint on the following document. (full code [here](https://github.com/palantir/python-language-server/blob/c3cab77a85b1de4af1aec1bafea6a7320d6baec5/test/plugins/test_pylint_lint.py))

```python
def hello()
    pass
```

pylint 2.3.1 reports back the 0 as the character where the syntax error is, however, pylint 2.4.1 is reporting back a 12 which is actually the exact location where a ':' must be introduced. 

The test is still expecting a value of 0 so the test fails.

items.title: How do you specify a path to a virtualenv?
items.body:
I'm trying to migrate my existing emacs setup to use `python-language-server` via eglot. I am currently using emacs with the [emacs-jedi](https://github.com/tkf/emacs-jedi/) package. I'm able to pass a path to a virtualenv that ends up instantiating a Jedi environment like this: `jedienv = jedi.create_environment(venv, safe=safe)`

I've read through the existing issues but I'm not sure of the answer (#143, for example). Is it to set `VIRTUAL_ENV` when running `pyls`? Is there a way to pass a path instead like described above?

items.title: No default source root
items.body:
If no `setup.py` is found, `Workspace.source_roots()` currently returns `[]`.

I think a preferable alternative would be to return the Workspace root (as the language client may have other means for detecting a source root).

items.title: Detect source roots for non-setuptools projects
items.body:
PEP518 allows for projects that are not dependent on setuptools, so may not contain a `setup.py`

`pyls` should also detect project roots based on the presence of a `pyproject.toml` file.

items.title: Incorrect mention of tox to run test suite
items.body:
Tox is a requirement for running the test suite, however, it's not listed in the setup.py and will not be installed when running `pip install .[test]`.

This was an issue when running test using the new Github Actions feature

export PYTHONHOME=$HOME/opt/pymol

;; LSP python mode
(use-package lsp-mode
  :ensure t
  :config
  (require 'lsp-clients)
  (add-hook 'prog-mode-hook 'lsp)
  
  (use-package lsp-ui
    :ensure t
    :config

  (use-package company-lsp

items.title: Why some capabilities are marked as supported when they're not
items.body:
```
LSP:      {'capabilities': {'renameProvider': True, 'executeCommandProvider': {'commands': []}, 'codeActionProvider': True, 'referencesProvider': True, 'signatureHelpProvider': {'triggerCharacters': ['(', ',']}, 'definitionProvider': True, 'experimental': {}, 'documentFormattingProvider': True, 'documentHighlightProvider': True, 'textDocumentSync': 2, 'documentRangeFormattingProvider': True, 'codeLensProvider': {'resolveProvider': False}, 'completionProvider': {'resolveProvider': False, 'triggerCharacters': ['.']}, 'documentSymbolProvider': True, 'hoverProvider': True}}
```
you can see here that `codeActionProvider` and `documentHighlightProvider` are marked as supported when they are not, this makes the client (here sublime's [LSP](https://github.com/tomv564/LSP)) send Requests on every click for nothing, can you disable these untill they are actually supported ?

items.title: Interested in sharing maintainership with the Spyder team?
items.body:
I'm the current [Spyder](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder) maintainer, an IDE to do data science in Python and made with Python too. We recently switched our code completion and linting architecture to use the Language Server Protocol, and as part of that effort we found some shortcomings and bugs in the `python-language-server` we'd be happy to help you with.

We already submitted a PR (see #542) and mentioned the importance of revisiting another one (see #445) but received no response. We've also seen other recent PRs have received no feedback as well.

Given the low activity in this repo during the last months and our need for the `python-language-server` to keep alive, we would like to know if you would be interested in sharing maintainership of this project with us. We have four developers ready to help improving things, one of whom (@andfoy) has already made contributions in the past and knows very well the server and client parts of the LSP.

We really hope you agree with our proposal. Otherwise we will be forced to create a fork of this project, something we'd really like to avoid to not split the community in two.

What do you think?

{
